channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Links North Korea to Syria’s Chemical Weapon Program
item.media:description: Smoke billowed last week after an airstrike on the besieged neighborhood of eastern Ghouta on the outskirts of Damascus.
item.description: An unreleased report says North Korea has evaded United Nations sanctions, providing Syria with materials for chemical weapons.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Italy Is Having an Election. Most Italians Are Too Depressed to Care.
item.media:description: In Taranto’s Tamburi neighborhood, residents have grown accustomed to watching young people move away.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Despite improvements, Italy’s economy remains moribund for millions of working people — a source of contempt about approaching national elections.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Trump Opens Door, Just Slightly, to Talking With North Korea
item.media:description: “We want to talk also,” President Trump said in remarks to American governors at the White House on Monday, referring to the North Koreans. But he quickly added: “only under the right conditions.”
item.description: “We want to talk also,” the president said. But hours later, the top U.S. diplomat on North Korea abruptly announced his departure.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: With Xi’s Power Grab, China Joins New Era of Strongmen
item.media:description: The Communist Party is abolishing limits on presidential terms, effectively allowing President Xi Jinping to lead China indefinitely.
item.description: Xi Jinping’s grab for power without term limits is the biggest move yet in a global shift by Putin, Erdogan and others toward unabashed authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Gay Mardi Gras in Australia Goes Corporate, Clashing With Activist Roots
item.media:description: Hundreds of people attended the Sissy Ball, sponsored by Red Bull, part of Sydney’s Mardi Gras, the city’s premier gay pride event.
item.media:credit: Brook Mitchell for The New York Times
item.description: The inclusion of more corporations in a festival sometimes comes at the expense of grass-roots activists and longtime participants.
item.dc:creator: TACEY RYCHTER and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Tourist From New York Is Arrested in Japan as Woman’s Body Parts Are Found
item.media:description: The apartment building in Osaka, Japan, where the police said they found the severed head of a Japanese woman.
item.media:credit: Makoto Kondo/Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.description: The man was being interrogated about the woman’s disappearance when he provided information that led to the grisly discoveries, the police told Japanese news media.
item.dc:creator: MAKIKO INOUE and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Angela Merkel Starts Grooming Successors, and One Stands Out
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, left, congratulated Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer after she was elected secretary general of the Christian Democratic Union in Berlin on Monday.
item.description: The chancellor’s Christian Democrats elected Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer as party general secretary, a signal that the Merkel era is nearing its end.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Syria Cease-Fire Must Take Effect Immediately, U.N. Chief Warns
item.media:description: Debris from shelling in Arbin, in the rebel-held enclave of eastern Ghouta.
item.description: The secretary general said it was “high time to stop this hell on earth,” and the U.N.’s top human rights official said permanent members of the Security Council must share the blame.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Xi Jinping Thought Explained: A New Ideology for a New Era
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, foreground, at the Communist Party Congress in Beijing last fall. Xi Jinping Thought, the Chinese leader’s political philosophy, will soon be enshrined in the Constitution.
item.description: Boiled down, the philosophy is a blueprint for consolidating and strengthening power at three levels: the nation, the party and Mr. Xi himself.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Why Build Kenya’s First Coal Plant? Hint: Think China
item.media:description: Unloading mangrove timber in Lamu, Kenya. A nearby coal-fired power station would be built and financed with Chinese help.
item.description: A project near a world heritage site in Kenya embodies a contradiction of Chinese climate leadership: Cutting coal use at home while promoting it abroad.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Toilet Paper Shortage Strikes Taiwan Amid Pricing Panic
item.media:description: A city inspector checked toilet paper supplies on Monday at a store in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, to ensure inventory was not being held back.
item.description: Retailers are having difficulty keeping the daily necessity in stock, as plans for price increases have sent consumers flocking to stores.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: Westport Journal: Success of Irish Trail Shows That Maybe You Can Eat the Scenery
item.media:description: Cyclists this month on the Great Western Greenway, a 26-mile trail laid on the bed of a disused railway in the west of Ireland.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: The Great Western Greenway, a cycling and walking trail on a disused railway, has helped bring jobs and recreation — whatever the weather.
item.dc:creator: ED O’LOUGHLIN

item.title: New Zealand’s Opposition Party Selects a New Leader
item.media:description: Simon Bridges, the new leader of the National Party, spoke with the party’s deputy leader, Paula Bennett, at the New Zealand Parliament in Wellington on Tuesday.
item.description: The center-right National Party chose Simon Bridges, 41, to lead it as it tries to counter the popularity of Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: South Africa’s New President Names Allies and Rivals to Cabinet
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa appointed several well-respected officials to key positions in his cabinet on Monday. He also retained some allies of his scandal-plagued predecessor.
item.description: Cyril Ramaphosa appointed well-regarded officials but also some allies of former President Jacob Zuma, as well as a provincial power broker.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Tempers Flare as Panama Hotel Owners Try to Oust Trump Company
item.media:description: The Trump International Hotel and Tower in Panama City, third building from left, in 2011.
item.description: Officials said they would investigate a dispute between the owners of a Panama City hotel that carries the Trump name and the Trump Organization.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution to Pressure Iran Over Yemen Missiles
item.media:description: Soldiers allied with Yemen’s Saudi-backed government on a mountainside exposed to Houthi rebels below on the outskirts of Sana, Yemen’s capital.
item.description: The United States denounced the Russia veto at the U.N. Security Council, which would have otherwise been approved.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Trump, DACA, Roger Goodell: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Hungary’s Opposition Sees Hope After Orban’s Candidate Falls
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary dismissed the opposition in a speech last week, but then his party’s candidate lost a local election.
item.description: The prime minister’s party suffered a surprising defeat in a local election just six weeks before a general election.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Slovak Journalist Found Shot to Death at Home
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard outside the site where Jan Kuciak, a journalist, and his fiancée, Martina Kusnirova, were killed in Velka Maca, Slovakia.
item.description: Jan Kuciak’s fiancée was also killed. The killings appeared related to his coverage of tax evasion and corruption in Slovakia.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA

item.title: After Anbang Takeover, China’s Deal Money, Already Ebbing, Could Slow Further
item.media:description: Anbang Insurance Group offices in Beijing. The Chinese government takeover of the company has energized the Trump administration, which has called for close looks at Chinese purchases of American companies.
item.description: Beijing’s takeover of one of the country’s biggest deal makers will likely intensify skepticism abroad over the Chinese government’s role in private business.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

item.title: Snow Falls in Rome, and the Eternal City Takes a Holiday
item.media:description: Tourists at the Colosseum in Rome during the snowfall on Monday.
item.description: With schools and parks in the city closed for the day, and hundreds of shops shuttered, many Romans took the unexpected blanket of white in cheerful stride.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Erdogan Tells a Weeping Girl, 6, She’d Receive Honors if Martyred
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey with Amine Tiras, 6, in Kahramanmaras on Saturday. “Maroon berets don’t cry,” he told her.
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Office, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: With Turkish armed forces engaged in a difficult battle in Syria, the president tried at a rally to bolster confidence.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, Backing a ‘Soft’ Brexit, Takes Aim at Conservatives
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour Party leader, arriving at Coventry University on Monday to outline the party’s new policy on Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union.
item.description: By embracing a customs union with the European Union, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party seeks to exploit deep fissures in the Tory cabinet.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: U.N. Chief: ‘Hell on Earth’ in Syria’s Ghouta Must End
item.description: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, urged that the resolution for a cease-fire in Syria, adopted by the Security Council over the weekend, be implemented and enforced.

item.title: ‘Creepy’ Interview Quizzes New Zealand’s Prime Minister on Conception
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand in Auckland last year. An Australian interviewer raised eyebrows in a “60 Minutes” segment on Sunday by alluding to speculation about when her baby was conceived.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: Questions by a “smitten” interviewer for “60 Minutes” in Australia startled Jacinda Ardern and outraged many viewers.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-MCLAY

item.title: South Korean Leader Urges U.S. and North Korea to Make Talks Possible
item.media:description: The South Korean president, Moon Jae-in, with hand raised; Ivanka Trump, third from right; and a North Korean general, Kim Yong-chol, second from right, attended the closing ceremony of the Olympics on Sunday in Pyeongchang, South Korea.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea voiced frustration with the two nations over their uncompromising stances on the North’s weapons program.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: A Quiet Jerusalem Neighborhood Gets a U.S. Embassy, and a Spotlight
item.media:description: The United States Embassy will be temporarily housed in American consular offices, center, in the Arnona neighborhood of Jerusalem.
item.description: The White House is accelerating plans to move diplomatic staff members to Jerusalem, with a small office to be set up in time for the 70th anniversary of the creation of the state of Israel, in May.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: President Xi Jinping’s Rise in China, as Covered by The Times
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China at Tiananmen Square in 2017. While Mr. Xi has used a steely edge to consolidate power, he has tried to convey an image of a softer, more humane leader than his predecessors.
item.description: With a proposed end to term limits, Mr. Xi could be around for much longer. Here’s an overview of how he came to command China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Rewrite Iran Deal? Europeans Offer a Different Solution: A New Chapter
item.media:description: President Trump with Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, right, and Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser, who have been able to talk him out of ending the Iran nuclear deal in the past.
item.description: The Europeans are creating an add-on agreement that would extend the existing deal with tighter restrictions, hoping that it will satisfy President Trump.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER, DAVID E. SANGER and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Nonfiction: Claiming the Title of United States Marine
item.media:description: Matt Young is the author of “Eat the Apple,” a memoir.
item.description: In his brutally honest memoir, “Eat the Apple,” Matt Young grapples with his experiences in the corps.
item.dc:creator: MARK BOWDEN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Lower Oil Prices Force Saudis to Widen Their Circle of Friends
item.media:description: American shale fields have flooded the oil market with crude, allowing the United States to import less from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which is led by Saudi Arabia, and begin exporting to markets once dominated by the kingdom.
item.description: The need to recharge its economy gives the kingdom new reasons to make common cause with China and Russia — overtures Washington is willing to accept.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: News Analysis: President Xi’s Strongman Rule Raises New Fears of Hostility and Repression
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in Beijing last year.
item.description: The decision to open a path to a third term for Mr. Xi has injected new uncertainty into international politics.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Barnaby Joyce Is Replaced as Australia’s Deputy Prime Minister
item.media:description: Barnaby Joyce, then Australia’s deputy prime minister, in Armidale, New South Wales, last week. He had been battered by scandals including an affair with a staff member who is now pregnant.
item.description: The conservative Mr. Joyce was felled by scandals including an affair with a staff member. Michael McCormack, the veterans affairs minister, succeeds him.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Retire at 55? In Brazil, It’s the Norm. But Can the Good Times Last?
item.media:description: Exercising in Rio de Janeiro. Brazil has one of the world’s most generous pension systems.
item.description: Brazil has one of the most generous social security systems in the world, but politicians across the spectrum have long seen it as unsustainable.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: At French Outpost in African Migrant Hub, Asylum for a Select Few
item.media:description: Asylum seekers at the United Nations compound in Niamey, Niger, last month.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: France is screening migrants before they take a perilous trip across the Mediterranean. A few get a plane ticket. For everyone else, the message is: Stay home.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Despite U.N. Cease-Fire, Syrian Forces Begin New Attacks in Rebel-Held Enclave
item.media:description: The Syrian government began new air strikes on Sunday in the Syrian rebel-held town of Douma, in the eastern Ghouta region on the outskirts of Damascus.
item.description: There were reports of a suspected chlorine attack by government forces, with one child killed in eastern Ghouta and 11 people suffering symptoms.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: In Nigeria, Another Mass Kidnapping Stirs Painful Memories and Anger
item.media:description: An empty classroom at the school in Dapchi, Nigeria, where dozens of girls went missing after Boko Haram attacked the village.
item.description: Dozens of schoolgirls have gone missing from a rural town in northern Nigeria and residents question why the government hasn’t learned lessons from a similar episode in 2014.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GOPEP and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Can South Korea’s Leader Turn an Olympic Truce Into a Lasting Peace?
item.media:description: Kim Yong-nam, the nominal head of state of North Korea, and Kim Yo-jong, sister of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, looking on behind President Moon Jae-in of South Korea and his wife, Kim Jung-sook, during the Olympic opening ceremony on Feb. 9.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in scored a potential diplomatic breakthrough when a senior North Korean official told him that the North was willing to open dialogue with the United States.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Amuay Journal: ‘A Bomb on the Doorstep’: Venezuela Fishermen Fight an Oil Giant
item.media:description: Fishing in Amuay Bay. The largest refinery complex in Venezuela has occasionally spewed contaminants into the water, threatening the livelihood of families in the area.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: For decades, a poor fishing village has tried to stop a state-run refinery from polluting a bay they share, but the battle has increasingly become one man’s charge.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Kurdish Leader Is Arrested in Prague at Turkey’s Request
item.media:description: Salih Muslim was detained in Prague after an Interpol “red notice” was issued by the Turkish government, which describes him as a terrorist.
item.description: Salih Muslim, the foreign affairs spokesman for the United States’ Kurdish allies in Syria, was detained in the Czech Republic after an extradition request.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: With Olympics Over, Team Korea Goes Back to Being 2 Countries
item.media:description: Athletes from North and South Korea marched together on Sunday during the closing ceremony of the 2018 Winter Olympics. Some waved the blue-and-white flag of a unified peninsula.
item.description: Athletes from North and South Korea waved the flags of their own countries as they arrived for the closing ceremony. Only time will tell whether Olympic diplomacy has had a lasting effect.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: North Korea Is Willing to Talk With U.S., South’s Leader Says
item.media:description: Shortly before the Winter Olympics’ closing ceremony on Sunday, Kim Yong-chol, top right, expressed North Korea’s willingness to meet with the United States, according to South Korea’s leader.
item.description: The move would be a potential diplomatic victory for President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who has been urging the two countries to talk.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: China Moves to Let Xi Stay in Power by Abolishing Term Limit
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China at the Communist Party congress in Beijing last October. Current law restricts the president to two terms.
item.description: The Communist Party has proposed revising the Constitution to end a two-term limit, which would let Xi Jinping remain president, perhaps indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.N. Security Council Votes in Favor of Syria Cease-Fire After Week of Bloodshed
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday in favor of a 30-day cease-fire in Syria.
item.description: The Council approved an immediate 30-day cease-fire after a recent bombardment of the Damascus suburb of eastern Ghouta killed hundreds of civilians.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Saving Koalas, and Other Marsupials, With Milk Almost as Good as Mom’s
item.media:description: Anne Bigham with some of the koalas she cares for at her home.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: When baby koalas or kangaroos need to be hand-reared, cow milk can sicken them. So a local company began creating custom formulas, and expanded to echidnas, sugar gliders and other Australian natives.
item.dc:creator: SERENA SOLOMON

item.title: If Trump Rips Up Nafta, Canada May Shrug, Not Shudder
item.media:description: “We will not be pushed into accepting any old deal, and no deal might very well be better for Canada than a bad deal,” Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said of Nafta in Chicago this month.
item.description: Because of changes to the global trading system, an end to the agreement is unlikely to be devastating for Canada, and could even have positive effects.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Women Are Free, and Armed, in Kurdish-Controlled Northern Syria
item.media:description: Women marching this month on the outskirts of Kobani, Syria, during a protest against a Turkish military offensive in the country. Many are waving the Rojava flag of Kurdish-controlled northern Syria.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Women wield significant authority in northern Syria — in the police, the courts and the militias — and the push for gender equality is spreading from Kurdish-majority areas to conservative Arab ones.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: European Ex-Officials Deny Being Paid by Manafort to Lobby for Ukraine
item.media:description: Paul Manafort at Federal District Court in Washington this month.
item.description: Mr. Manafort paid 2 million euros to former European officials to lobby for Ukraine’s then pro-Russian government, a new indictment says.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and JASON HOROWITZ
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
